items.title: Coverage only runs if --enable-coverage is present in command line
items.body:
According to https://github.com/kmmbvnr/django-jenkins/blob/master/django_jenkins/apps.py#L17 - coverage is only run if `--enable-coverage` is present in the `sys.argv` list. However, it seems to counter the possibility to run manage.py tasks directly from the code.

For example, I have a minimal django package and a very minimal django project that's supposed only to run init tests. The settings file is called `run_tests.py` and the bottom of it states:

```python
if __name__ == '__main__':
    # set the ENV
    sys.path.append(os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'src'))
    os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = 'src.minimal_django_project'

    from django.core import management

    # Execute jenkins task directly
    management.execute_from_command_line(
       [__file__, 'jenkins', '--enable-coverage', 'mypackage']
    )
```

However, `sys.argv` is empty. The way django handles this by default is to check for `sys.argv` if any are present:

```python
class ManagementUtility(object):
    """
    Encapsulates the logic of the django-admin and manage.py utilities.

    A ManagementUtility has a number of commands, which can be manipulated
    by editing the self.commands dictionary.
    """
    def __init__(self, argv=None):
        self.argv = argv or sys.argv[:]
        self.prog_name = os.path.basename(self.argv[0])
        self.settings_exception = None
```

This is not a critical bug, but something that could be thought of in future releases.

items.title: Simplify use of cloc instead of sloccount.
items.body: The sloccount plugin for Jenkins can process output from either sloccount or cloc. Since cloc supports more languages (e.g. I'm writing front-end code in Elm) it would be helpful to have an easy way to choose cloc. What would be the most sensible way to make this possible in django-jenkins? Add a django_jenkins.tasks.run_cloc task?

items.title: Add documentation for pipeline Jenkinsfile syntax support
items.body:
I tried to integrate this into my pipeline job on jenkins. See #351 for most recent documentation :books:. ;)

I'd like to add description on how to use this plugin with the new [jenkins pipeline syntax](https://jenkins.io/doc/book/pipeline/jenkinsfile/).

There is this pull request on cubertura to add support for `coverage.xml` from pipeline. 
https://github.com/jenkinsci/cobertura-plugin/pull/55

I also commented on https://github.com/jenkinsci/cobertura-plugin/issues/50#issuecomment-262419362 where I described how to use https://github.com/cwacek/cobertura-clover-transform and use clover instead of cobertura as a temp workaround, but it failed on my side.

Here's how I managed to get `coverage.xml` and `junit.xml` to work in jenkins:
I cloned https://github.com/mbarrien/cobertura-plugin/tree/pipeline (pipeline branch, that's the pr 55 above), compiled the plugin:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/mbarrien/cobertura-plugin/
cd cobertura-plugin
mvn install
```
This generated the `.hpi` plugin which I installed from `Jenkins -> Manage Jenkins -> Configure Plugins -> Advanced` and installed Cobertura plugin from there.

My app name is in `PROJECT_APPS` tuple as requested by django-jenkins. Here's what my `Jenkinsfile` looks like:
```groovy
try {
sh '''
  #!/usr/bin/env sh
  source venv/bin/activate
  python manage.py jenkins --enable-coverage
'''
currentBuild.result = 'SUCCESS'
} catch(Exception err) {
currentBuild.result = 'FAILURE'
}

// Cobertura test coverage
step([$class: 'CoberturaPublisher', coberturaReportFile: 'reports/coverage.xml'])

// JUnit test results
step([$class: 'JUnitResultArchiver', testResults: 'reports/junit.xml'])
```

Everything seems to work fine:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1264761/20582110/2129f510-b1ac-11e6-9e5c-88f41c73da7c.png)

But there's one thing left I'm still fighting with, I created an issue on Cobertura's side:
https://github.com/jenkinsci/cobertura-plugin/issues/61
I'd be very happy if someone has an idea on this!

items.title: Move tutorial to something like ReadTheDocs so anyone can contribute
items.body:
> For more details see the generic tutorial: https://sites.google.com/site/kmmbvnr/home/django-jenkins-tutorial

I'd like to edit this as I found a typo:
> add `django_jenins` to `INSTALLED_APPS` in `settings.py`

Would be

> add `django_jenkins` to `INSTALLED_APPS` in `settings.py`

> Add to you project file named requirements.pip with all project dependencies list

Would be

> Add to your project `requirements.txt` with all project dependencies list

etc.


If you add me to contributors, I could find the time to set this up in Read The Docs and convert the google document.

I'd be really happy to give a hand as this project is very handy :)

I've created https://readthedocs.org/projects/django-jenkins/ and added kmmbvnr as a maintainer.

> This repository doesn't have a valid webhook set up. That means it won't be rebuilt on commits to the repository. 
> You can resync your webhook to fix this.

items.title: Finding test locations on Python 3.3+
items.body:
I just ran into an error in django_jenkins where it failed to find the tested locations (as part of the management command).

Traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "manage.py", line 10, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 353, in execute_from_command_line
    utility.execute()
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 345, in execute
    self.fetch_command(subcommand).run_from_argv(self.argv)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/test.py", line 30, in run_from_argv
    super(Command, self).run_from_argv(argv)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 348, in run_from_argv
    self.execute(*args, **cmd_options)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/test.py", line 74, in execute
    super(Command, self).execute(*args, **options)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/raven/contrib/django/management/__init__.py", line 41, in new_execute
    return original_func(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 399, in execute
    output = self.handle(*args, **options)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django_jenkins/management/commands/jenkins.py", line 152, in handle
    tested_locations = self.get_tested_locations(test_labels)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/jobs/ima-idb-develop/workspace/env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/django_jenkins/management/commands/jenkins.py", line 184, in get_tested_locations
    locations.append(os.path.dirname(app_config.module.__file__))
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '__file__'
```

The underlying cause is that we forgot to create a `__init__.py` file in the root of our project app, which is [legal since Python 3.3](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.3.html#pep-420-implicit-namespace-packages).

The offending code is:

```
    app_config = apps.get_containing_app_config(test_label)
            if app_config is not None:
                locations.append(os.path.dirname(app_config.module.__file__))
            else:
                warnings.warn('No app found for test: {0}'.format(test_label))
```

The `app_config` exists, only the module is implicit and doesn't have a `__file__` attribute. According to [PEP0420](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0420/#id24) this module has a `__path__` attribute which is an iterable of paths:

```
(BPdb) app_config.module.__path__
_NamespacePath(['/home/bbt/coding/maykin/imadb/projects'])
```

It seems to me that in that case the code should look like this:

```
for test_label in test_labels:
    app_config = apps.get_containing_app_config(test_label)
    if app_config is not None:
        try:
            locations.append(os.path.dirname(app_config.module.__file__))
        except AttributeError:  # implicit namespace package
            locations += list(app_config.module.__path__)
    else:
        warnings.warn('No app found for test: {0}'.format(test_label))
```

Thoughts?

items.title: Flake8 test broken with flake8 >=2.5.0
items.body:
Am getting the following error:

```
File "django_jenkins/tasks/run_flake8.py", line 98, in run
    pep8style.input_dir(os.path.relpath(location))
AttributeError: 'StyleGuide' object has no attribute 'input_dir'
```

I've taken a quick look into the issue and in the 2.5 release of flake8 the class flake8.engine.StyleGuide is now a wrapper around the pep8.StyleGuide rather than a sub class of which the input_dir method is not implemented by the wrapper.

The simple workaround for now is to install flake8<2.5.0

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'Reporter'
items.body:
This breaks any builds with coverage on `django-jenkins == 0.18.1`

``` stacktrace
./manage.py jenkins -v 3 --pep8-exclude="*migrations*,*tests*" --coverage-exclude="*migrations*,*tests*"

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./manage.py", line 13, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
  File "~/.virtualenv/drund/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 351, in execute_from_command_line
    utility.execute()
  File "~/.virtualenv/drund/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 343, in execute
    self.fetch_command(subcommand).run_from_argv(self.argv)
  File "~/.virtualenv/drund/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 190, in fetch_command
    klass = load_command_class(app_name, subcommand)
  File "~/.virtualenv/drund/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 41, in load_command_class
    return module.Command()
  File "~/.virtualenv/drund/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django_jenkins/management/commands/jenkins.py", line 62, in __init__
    for module_name in self.get_task_list()]
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'Reporter'
```

It looks like the culprit is `with_coverage.py` has no class `Reporter` instead it has `CoverageReporter`

At the end of `with_coverage.py` I added

``` python
Reporter = CoverageReporter
```

And that worked.

I don't know if there is a specific reason the class is named `CoverageReporter`

The solution is either change the class name or set `Reporter = CoverageReporter`

items.title: possible compatibility issue with Django 1.9
items.body:
Using django-jenkins with Django 1.8 results in the following warning:

```
django.utils.deprecation.RemovedInDjango19Warning: django.utils.importlib will be removed in Django 1.9.
```

The following file seems to be cause:
django-jenkins/django_jenkins/tasks/with_coverage.py

I guess the following statement:

```
from django.utils.importlib import import_module
```

needs to be changed to:

```
from importlib import import_module
```

items.title: Errors with coverage 4.0
items.body:
Coverage 4.0 is still in beta, but django-jenkins will not work with it. See http://coverage.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changes.html#version-4-0b2-pre-release-22-august-2015 for backward incompatibilities.

items.title: README should mention python/django compatibility
items.body:
I just tried upgrading `django-jenkins` from my old version (0.14.1) to release 0.16.3, and encountered an import error.

The module I'm missing, `django.test.runner`, was [only added in Django 1.6](https://github.com/django/django/commit/9012833af857e081b515ce760685b157638efcef), so any Django > 1.6 therefore cannot be (easily?) supported.

I suggest mentioning Django/Python versions supported (and the reasoning behind dropped/omitted versions) for easier upgrades/changes. I just realized I can look in `tox.ini` for what is tested, but still, would be nice if it was explained in the documentation.

items.title: tasks don't use STATIC_ROOT
items.body:
Was wondering why run_csslint and run_jshint doesn't look at the STATIC_ROOT.

It get's the list like so:

```
        files = list(
            static_files_iterator(apps_locations + list(getattr(settings, 'STATICFILES_DIRS', [])),
                                  extension='.css',
                                  ignore_patterns=options['csslint_exclude'].split(',')))
```

apps_locations is the list of either INSTALLED_APPS or PROJECT_APPS, and STATICFILES_DIRS is the additional directories, but it doesn't add STATIC_ROOT. We can't add STATIC_ROOT to STATICFILES_DIRS as django throws an error. We can't also specify extra paths to search for with the tasks.

items.title: XML reporter with UnicodeDecodeError when traceback contains non-ascii content
items.body:
EXMLTestResult._add_tb_to_test puts some string content into XML attributes and text. ETree.write() then calls .encode() on those bytes, which implicitly tries to de-code them into unicode so it can encode them again, and that fails if the bytes aren't in 0-127.

Throwing a few smart_text calls in there seems to resolve things. I'll submit a pull request with that tomorrow.

Because flake8 gives the highest priority to the command line arguments.

items.title: Coverage can't find source code in Jenkins for Django project not in git root
items.body:
Say that you have a Django project in a subdirectory of the version control root. 
Enabling coverage on such project will work fine but Jenkins won't be able to find the source to display in its source browser.

This is mainly because the jenkins task has to be run in the Django root (or else it won't run any tests) but Jenkins will compute paths relative to its workspace root.

I have worked around this by adding a line in my Jenkins build script such as:
sed -i 's/filename="/filename="my_django_project\//g' reports/coverage.xml

Maybe this issue is not to be fixed by django-jenkins itself but I believe that it should at least be documented.

items.title: django-jenkins doesn't work with coverage.py 4.0a1
items.body:
Hi, there are a few things you are doing that are not part of the publicly supported API of coverage.py, and one of them is breaking with 4.0a1.
First, you should import "coverage" like this:

```
from coverage import coverage
```

Because you are importing from "coverage.control", it doesn't work with coverage.py 4.0a1.
Secondly, I see you are calling `_harvest_data` directly.  You shouldn't need to do this, as the leading underscore indicates.
If I can help to get django-jenkins working using only the public APIs, please let me know.

items.title: Hard to diagnose error when an app is in PROJECT_APPS but not in INSTALLED_APPS
items.body:
With Django 1.7, in the `jenkins` management command, you're calling `get_containing_app_config` on every app name in PROJECT_APPS.

If the app isn't in INSTALLED_APPS, a mistake that can happen easily in large projects with complex settings combinations, `get_containing_app_config` will return `None`.

In that case, the management commands fails after the tests finish running:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./manage.py", line 10, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 385, in execute_from_command_line
    utility.execute()
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 377, in execute
    self.fetch_command(subcommand).run_from_argv(self.argv)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/test.py", line 50, in run_from_argv
    super(Command, self).run_from_argv(argv)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 288, in run_from_argv
    self.execute(*args, **options.__dict__)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/commands/test.py", line 71, in execute
    super(Command, self).execute(*args, **options)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django/core/management/base.py", line 338, in execute
    output = self.handle(*args, **options)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django_jenkins/management/commands/jenkins.py", line 110, in handle
    tested_locations = self.get_tested_locations(test_labels)
  File ".../lib/python3.3/site-packages/django_jenkins/management/commands/jenkins.py", line 152, in get_tested_locations
    locations.append(os.path.dirname(app_config.module.__file__))
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'module'
```

The reason for this error is far from obvious. You end up pdb'ing in django_jenkins :-)

It would be nice to handle it more gracefully, for instance by checking if the return value of `get_containing_app_config` is `None` or by validating that PROJECT_APPS is a subset of INSTALLED_APPS.

items.title: Django 1.7 migrations raise pep8 and pylint errors
items.body:
I believe it was meant to be a feature to run all linters on Django 1.7 migrations and only ignore Soth migrations: https://github.com/kmmbvnr/django-jenkins/commit/b49d6ebf003ed6c324c3f62b4b872e61103b430f

Unfortunatelly, Django 1.7 auto-generated migrations fail on pep8 and pyflakes:

pep8.report example:

```
my_app/migrations/0001_initial.py:17:80: E501 line too long (114 > 79 characters)
```

pyflakes.report example:

```
my_app/migrations/0021_my_migration.py:4: [E] PYFLAKES:'models' imported but unused
my_app/migrations/0034_merge.py:4: [E] PYFLAKES:'models' imported but unused
```

And many other, similar errors.

In my opinion, as Django 1.7 auto-generated migrations are NOT guaranteed to be pep8/pyflakes-compatible, default django-jenkins configuration should not run linters on them. It's an overkill to force to either manually edit every migration or to manually set a different configuration just to ignore migrations.

If south_migrations are ignored, so should be Django 1.7 migrations.

items.title: django-jenkins plan
items.body:
Hello,
I am incorporating django-jenkins into our CI and am starting to write some tests. Along with unittest2, I am planning on using either behave or lettuce. I am still on django 1.5, upgrading to 1.6 in a couple months, likely, so I am using django-jenkins 0.14.1. I ran into an import error discussed in #186 where it was said that behave support is being removed. Also I noticed that lettuce support is being dropped because of python3. 

I would really like to use django-jenkins, but don't want to have to rewrite a bunch of tests down the road. Since I am just starting what do you suggest I use? What does the future of django-jenkins look like? 
For example should I use behave now with django 1.5 and python 2.7 and hope it's still supported when i upgrade to django 1.6 and python 3? Or should I use lettuce instead. 

Thanks!

items.body:
After upgrading from Django 1.4 to 1.6 I am seeing 45% swings in coverage reports (from 90% line coverage to 43%). The coverage reports are also showing very inconsistent results from file to file and run to run... even for lines that I KNOW have been covered... like imports. Running coverage reports using nose+coverage yield the expected 90%.

Re-running the exact same tests under Django 1.4 (with django-jenkins 0.14.1) again yields correct (90%) coverage reports. Have not tested under Django 1.5

items.title: Omit option from coverage.rc not used in coverage
items.body:
django 1.5.4, coverage 3.6, django-jenkins 1.14.1

Since version 1.14.1, the omit option in a configured coverage.rc file does not work anymore.
The problem is that in with_coverage.py the call to coverage() (around line 50) has changed to include the parameter omit=self.exclude_options.
This seems to be wrong for 2 reasons:
- exclude_options are excluded modules, while omit uses reg expressions for file paths, so they are not compatible
- as omit is now set to an empty array by default, the settings from coverage.rc are overridden because of the sequence the config is initialized in coverage/control.py

Downgrading to 1.14.0 fixes the issue.

items.title: omit in coverage rcfile being ignored
items.body:
Perhaps I have incorrectly formatted my coverage.rc file, but upgrading from 0.14.0 to 0.14.1, omitting test files from tests doesn't appear to be working.

I'm using

```
./manage.py jenkins access --coverage-rcfile=.coveragerc
```

The file structure looks something like

```
.coveragerc
manage.py
reports/
    coverage.xml
djangoapp/
    access/
        tests.py
        models.py
        ...
    ...
...
```

Note that this is an older layout than I guess what django is currently recommending. I swear they change it on every major release.

And my .coveragerc file is

```
[run]
branch = True
omit = *migrations*
       *tests*


[report]
omit = /usr/*
       src/*
       *migrations*
       *tests*
```

In 0.14.0, djangoapp/access/tests.py is correctly omitted in coverage.xml, but in 0.14.1, it is back, and trying a variety of omits doesn't appear to change anything. I also renaming .coveragerc to coverage.rc to be more consistent with defaults.
